verse: But he knows the way that I take; when he has tested me, I will come forth as gold. My feet have closely followed his steps; I have kept to his way without turning aside. (Job 23:10-11)
reflection:
I believe there is one thing and one thing only that can make a difference in how we face our every day trials, even little ones, it is our attitude. We can have the attitude of the Pharaoh of Egypt, who when confronted by Moses and the ten plagues from God, who grumbled, and griped, and became stubborn, causing more woes to come upon him. Or that of Job, who at the loss of all his possessions, even his own health,
succumbed to the will of God and remained faithful. That kind of commitment to Christ will give us eternal life, happiness and joy. Remember: (Phil. 4:13) I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me. And (Ro. 8:28) And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God.
prayer: Dear Lord, in every circumstance, grant me sincere repentance, help me to remain patient in all Your ways, so that I may lift my face to behold You and give You praise. Amen.

verse: Search me, God, and know my heart; test me and know my anxious thoughts. See if there is any offensive way in me, and lead me in the way everlasting. (Psalm 139:23-24)
reflection:
Searched me and known me! ~ What this is saying is that God is omniscient;
He knows everything about us. ~ This includes knowing our every action, our every thought, even our future, even our very future, with perfect intimacy. Like the Psalmist we should ask God to extend His omniscience to our inner life, to search out the traces of sin in our lives, so that God's presence might lead us to everlasting life.
prayer: Thank You Lord for knowing us so completely. Lead us to agree with your judgement against sin, especially with the sins in our own lives. Cleanse us with Christ's blood, born of the virgin Mary, who is present for our or salvation in His Word and sacraments. Amen.

verse: He has saved us and called us to a holy life-not because of anything we have done but because of his own purpose and grace. This grace was given us in Christ Jesus before the beginning of time, (2 Timothy 1:9)
reflection: He has called us to a holy life. Though Paul may have been speaking primarily about the pastoral office that he and Timothy shared, his reference to a holy calling applies to all who live by faith. A Christian's daily work is indeed a holy calling and a priestly work because of God's gift of faith, not because of our works.  Christian holiness is not rooted in what we do, but in God's work for us and through us in Christ. Purpose and grace, before the beginning of time. God knew, even before creation, that in the fullness of time, He would give His Son to die for us. Before we existed, yes, even before the foundation of the world was laid ~ when, of course, we could do nothing good ~ we were chosen by grace in Christ to salvation, according to God's purpose.
prayer: Thank You Lord Jesus, for Your promise never to leave me or forsake me. Amen.

prayer: Dear Lord I pray that Your Spirit would help us in our frailty, assuring us of Your steadfast love. never leave us or forsake us. turn our complaints into prayers and our condemnation into glory. Amen.

subject: Truths to live by
verse: If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just and will forgive us our sins and purify us from all unrighteousness.  (1 John 1:9)
reflection: Confession is suppose to free us to enjoy fellowship with Christ. It should ease our conscience and lighten our cares. But some Christians do not understand how it works. They feel so guilty they confess the same sins over and over; then they wonder if they might have forgotten something. Other Christians believe that God forgives them when they confess, but if they died with unconfessed sin, they would be forever lost. These Christians do not understand that God wants to forgive us. He allowed His beloved Son to die just so He could offer us pardon. When we come to Christ, he forgives all the sins we have committed. We don't need to confess the sins of our past all over again, and we don't need to fear that God will reject us if we don't keep our slate perfectly clean. . . Of course we should continue to confess sins, but not because failure to do so will make us lose our salvation. Our relationship with Christ is secure. ~ Instead, we should confess so that we can enjoy maximum fellowship and joy with Him. Remember, ~ True confession also involves a commitment not to continue to sin. ~ We wouldn't be genuinely confessing our sins to God if we planned to commit them again and just wanted temporary forgiveness. Remember, ~ We should always pray for strength to defeat temptation the next time we face it. Question, ~ If God has forgiven us for our sins because of Christ's death, why must we confess our sins? ? ? Answer, ~ In admitting our sins and receiving Christ's cleansing we are, (1) agreeing with God that our sin truly is sin and that we are willing to turn form it, (2) ensuring that we don't conceal our sins from Him and consequently from ourselves. and (3) recognizing our tendency to sin and relying on His power to overcome it.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, give us hearts to believe and to know ourselves as we are. So then we may truthfully confess our sins, trusting in Your forgiveness and mercy. Amen.

subject: Truths to live by
verse: For it has been granted to you on behalf of Christ not only to believe in him, but also to suffer for him, (Philippians 1:29)
reflection: Most people would say that Paul was unique. Paul considered it a privilege to suffer for Christ. We do not by nature consider suffering a privilege. prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, give Your people grace to recognize that all praise belongs to You alone, even during times of suffering. Amen.

"For there is one God and one mediator between God and mankind, 
the man Christ Jesus, who gave himself as a ransom for all people.

us bring us together again ~ He is Jesus who is both God and man.

He paid our penalty for sin and purchased our freedom. . .

Have you let Him bring you to the Father?

lovingly assigned us and to live out our vocations in submissiveness
to You and Your Word. . . Amen.

subject: Truths to live by
verse: God made him who had no sin to be sin for us, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God. (2 Corinthians 5:21)
reflection: Give this some thought: When we trust Christ, we make an exchange. He takes our sin and makes us right with God. Our sin was laid on Christ at His crucifixion. . . His righteousness is given to us at our conversion. This is what Christians mean by Christ's atonement for sin. In the world, bartering works only when two people exchange goods of relatively equal value. But God offers to trade for something completely worthless. How grateful we should be for His kindness to us.
prayer: Dear Lord, impress upon my heart the greatness of Your grace to me, by the power of Your Holy Spirit, so that I can walk confidently by faith until I see You gloriously face to face. Amen.

subject: Truths to live by
verse: He was despised and rejected by mankind, a man of suffering, and familiar with pain. Like one from whom people hide their faces he was despised, and we held him in low esteem. Surely he took up our pain and bore our suffering, yet we considered him punished by God, stricken by him, and afflicted. (Isaiah 53:3-4)
reflection: This man of sorrows was despised and rejected by those around Him, and He is still despised and rejected by many today. Some reject Christ by standing against Him. Others despise Christ and the great gift of salvation. Do you despise Him, reject, or accept Him? When we think of all the years it would be before this was going to happen, we must think of it as God pulling aside the curtain of time to let the people of Isaiah's day look ahead to the suffering of the future Messiah and the resulting forgiveness made available to all people.
prayer: O Lord, what a wondrous love is this that caused our Lord Jesus of bliss to bear the dreadful curse of my soul. Amen.

subject: Truths to live by
verse: But he was pierced for our transgressions, he was crushed for our iniquities; the punishment that brought us peace was on him, and by his wounds we are healed. We all, like sheep, have gone astray, each of us has turned to our own way; and the LORD has laid on him the iniquity of us all. (Isaiah 53:5-6)
reflection: Isaiah says we are like sheep ~ no this is no April fool joke. Who wants to argue the point? ~ Are we not all guilty of straying? Yet God sent His Messiah to bring us back into the fold. We have the hindsight to see and know the identity of the promised Messiah, who has come and died for our sins. But if we know all that Jesus did and still reject Him, ~ tell me why people still think that their sins are no greater than that of the ancient Israelites, who could not see what we have seen? ? ? Have you given your life to Jesus Christ, the Good Shepherd (Jn. 10:11-16), or are you still like wondering sheep?
prayer: O Lord, what wondrous love, once again I pray, What wondrous love this is. That caused my Lord to bear the dreadful curse for my soul. Amen.
